In Corsica, on-farm cheese making is defended by an association of farmers (of dairy goats and dairy ewes), Casgiu Casanu, which has existed since 1998 and has been locally and nationally active. It defends farmers' interests regarding the evolution of european and national regulations. It provides specific training (hygiene, different processes for transformation of milk) and it has developped an efficient structure for cheeses' transport, in Corsica and in the French Continent. As on-farm cheese making often plays a key role in preserving traditional know-how, it is recognized in a geographical indication (PDO Brocciu) and plays a central role in the on-going labelling project (5 different projets regarding different types of local cheeses: venachese, sartinese, calinzanincu, niolincu, bastelicacciu). Of-farm cheese making is particularly present in mountainous areas where it is one of the remaining (agricultural) activities. It contributes to the villages' vividness. In its traditional form, this type of husbandry contributes to land management near those villages. New forms of husbandry have developed more recently, which are more intensive (use of foreign breeds, indoors husbandry) and less interconnected to the local ecosystem. The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. Which cheese to produce ? How to process milk ? How to produce milk ? Those are questions that can be answered individually or collectively (common-pool resources such as summer pastures and pastoral surfaces, local breeds, etc.). Those choices can be in continuity with local tradition and know-how, or not. The innovation is related to New governance systems. The land use systems involved are Grassland, Natural land and agrosylvopastoral systems (schrubs, forests of oaks - accorns, meadows). The local assets include Natural and cultural.   Dairy husbandry and production of Cheese is observable in every other MRLs. On-farm cheese making is not a specificity of Corsica, but its anteriority is remarkable. Its current expressions gives us insight about how tradition and novelty can interact and produce resilience for territories in recession.
